text:
JAR files loaded into the WEB-INF/lib directory of one application are 
available to all web applications.  If multiple versions of a JAR file exist in 
different applications, the version loaded from the first application to load 
is used.

For example, you have two web applications: foo and bar.  Foo has version 1.0 
of a JAR file.  Bar has version 1.1.  When both applications are loaded in 
webapps, they both use version 1.1 despite the fact that Foo should be using 
1.0.  Either webapp functions correctly if the other app is not in Tomcat.
creator: jwinters@inst.strykercorp.com

text:
Created attachment 74
Zip file containing WAR files and source code of example app exposing this bug.
creator: jwinters@inst.strykercorp.com

text:
This example uses a tag library, and indeed it looks like there's something 
wrong going on.
According to my testing, it doesn't happen with servlets or other classes (only 
taglibs).
creator: remm@apache.org

text:
Created attachment 76
Zip file with modified example app including servlets and other classes.  Bug still occurs with servlets - it isn't limited to custom tags.
creator: jwinters@inst.strykercorp.com
remm@apache.org
text:
Actually, I didn't test that. I just tried to load a servlet from another 
webapp. For example, if foo doesn't have classA in its repositories and tries 
to load it it will fail with a class not found (the opposite is true too).
Yet somehow class conflicts occur ...

Created attachment 78
Zip file with modified example.  Servlets can be accessed from the wrong app, note to follow.
creator: jwinters@inst.strykercorp.com
jwinters@inst.strykercorp.com
text:
The latest attachment shows that a servlet can be loaded from a JAR file in 
another app.  If only the foo application is loaded, running the checkExist 
servlet returns a ClassNotFoundException as it should.  If bar is also loaded, 
running checkExist in foo works.  Foo is accessing the servlet from the bar 
application JAR file.

The problem should have been fixed now. The URLs generated for the JARs in the 
web applications were identical when the JARs had the same name, which was 
causing problems in the JDK JAR URL cache.
Your example is now working good :)
Thanks !
creator: remm@apache.org

text: *** Bug 1906 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: remm@apache.org
